title: Andrew Yang (Taiwanese politician)
text:
Andrew Yang (; born 15 May 1955) was the 29th Minister of <a href="Ministry%20of%20National%20Defense%20%28Republic%20of%20China%29">National Defense</a> of the <a href="Republic%20of%20China">Republic of China</a>, having served 1–6 August 2013. Before this, he was the Deputy Minister of National Defense from 2009 to 2013.
Education.
Yang is a graduate of <a href="Fu%20Jen%20Catholic%20University">Fu Jen Catholic University</a> and the <a href="London%20School%20of%20Economics%20and%20Political%20Science">London School of Economics and Political Science</a> of the <a href="University%20of%20London">University of London</a>. He specialized in the study of <a href="United%20States">United States</a>-<a href="Taiwan">Taiwan</a>-<a href="China">China</a> relations and <a href="national%20security">national security</a>. He had devoted much of his time in the research of building a cross-Taiwan Strait military mutual trust, the <a href="People%27s%20Liberation%20Army">People's Liberation Army</a> and regional security while teaching at universities and other academic institutions in Taiwan.
Early career.
Yang had been a research associate at the Sun Yat-sen Center for Policy Studies of the <a href="National%20Sun%20Yat-sen%20University">National Sun Yat-sen University</a> in <a href="Kaohsiung">Kaohsiung</a> in 1986–2000. Yang had been the adviser for the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Republic%20of%20China%29">Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a> in 1998, <a href="Mainland%20Affairs%20Council">Mainland Affairs Council</a> and <a href="Ministry%20of%20National%20Defense%20%28Republic%20of%20China%29">Ministry of National Defense</a> since 2000. He was a lecturer at the <a href="National%20Sun%20Yat-sen%20University">National Sun Yat-sen University</a> in 2000–2009.
Prior to his appointment as ROC Deputy Minister of National Defense in 2009, Yang was the Secretary-General of the <a href="China%20Council%20of%20Advanced%20Policy%20Studies">China Council of Advanced Policy Studies</a>, a Taipei-based think tank concentrating on military affairs. He also has traveled frequently to the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> where he maintains a close relationship with top officials from <a href="The%20Pentagon">The Pentagon</a>.
ROC Minister of National Defense.
Ministerial post appointment.
On 29 July 2013, Premier <a href="Jiang%20Yi-huah">Jiang Yi-huah</a> announced a <a href="Executive%20Yuan">cabinet</a> reshuffle for the first time since he took the Premiership on 18 February 2013. Yang was appointed to be the <a href="Ministry%20of%20National%20Defense%20%28Republic%20of%20China%29">Minister of National Defense</a> replacing <a href="Kao%20Hua-chu">Kao Hua-chu</a> who had earlier tendered his resignation several times due to the death scandal of Corporal <a href="Hung%20Chung-chiu">Hung Chung-chiu</a> on 4 July 2013. Right after his appointment, Yang promised that he would review military administration, professional certification and supervisory systems to improve human rights. Yang was the first civilian to head the post since <a href="Ma%20Ying-jeou">Ma Ying-jeou</a> took the Presidential office on 20 May 2008.
Resignation.
On 6 August 2013, Yang resigned from his position due to plagiarism allegations. Yang told the press that some portions of the book he had written back in 2007 were written by his friends without proper citations. He decided to resign from his post to maintain the reputation of the Executive Yuan. Deputy Minister of National Defense, <a href="Kao%20Kuang-chi">Kao Kuang-chi</a> temporarily headed the ministry on 7 August until the official ministerial appointment of <a href="Yen%20Ming">Yen Ming</a> by the <a href="Executive%20Yuan">Executive Yuan</a> on 8 August 2013.
